dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence -- complete silence for the urbanite, though the  oncoming darkness is punctuated by the sounds of farm cou a few birds, a distant rumble of thunder from some heavy  clouds on the horizon, a dog's barking. CAMERA PANS the green, squared-off flatland, lit only by fine sunset in its final throes. Then, gradually, startin from nothing, a rumble is heard, quickly growing louder a louder until the sound of a train can be recognized. CAMERA PANS quickly, discovering the railroad line atop a man-made rise of land, and the speeding passenger train i upon us, flashing by with a roar. Then, as if from nowhere, the figure of a man hits the  embankment and rolls crazily down to the bottom into the  thick underbrush alongside the tracks.

dialogues.speaker: BODY
dialogues.text: It lies in the bushes, still, unmoving -- dead. CAMERA PA AWAY to the quiet peaceful countryside as the sound of th train fades off until there is silence once more. TITLE MUSIC begins with a crash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A handsome and elegant hotel perched on the mountain-side overlooking the French resort town. A large, open sun dec tables, gaily colored parasols, sun bathers. One of the latter is REGINA LAMPERT, a lovely young girl. She is, besides taking in the sun, involved in her favori activity -- eating. Then -- a dark, ominous shape intrudes in the f.g. FOCUS  CHANGES to bring into sharp relief a revolver -- shining, black and ugly in the sunlight. REGGIE, unaware of her danger, continues to eat. The finger tightens around the trigger and finally the gu shoots -- a stream of water arcs, with unerring aim, stra into REGGIE's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Including JEAN-LOUIS, a French boy of six or so. REGGIE l at him sternly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in for trouble) Oh, la.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me you didn't know it was  loaded. (calling) Sylvie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SYLVIE GAUDET, French, attractive, blonde, in her early  thirties, comes from the railing of the sun deck to join  REGGIE and JEAN-LOUIS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't there something constructive  he can do -- like start an avalanche?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to JEAN-LOUIS) Va jouer, mon ange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JEAN-LOUIS scampers off, content to have gotten off so  lightly. SYLVIE notices REGGIE's lunch which consists of  cold chicken, potato salad, rolls and butter, wine and co

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you start to eat like this  something is the matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer from REGGIE. SYLVIE begins reading a magazine a REGGIE continues eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sylvie -- I'm getting a divorce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Г‡a alors! From Charles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's the only husband I've got. I  tried to make it work, I really have --  but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how to explain it. I'm  just too miserable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REGGIE picks up a chicken leg and starts off. SYLVIE rega the devastated table before following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is infuriating that your  unhappiness does not turn to fat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A magnificent indoor, glass-enclosed pool, the vista of s covered mountains seen through the ceiling-high windows  beyond. REGGIE and SYLVIE are passing through, their  conversation continuing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why do you want a divorce?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I don't love him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that is no reason to get a  divorce!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An open balcony running around two sides of the pool, sun worshippers lying in deck-chairs. REGGIE and SYLVIE appea their conversation continuing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a rich husband and this year's  clothes you will not find it difficult  to make some new friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sitting) I admit I moved to Paris because I  was tired of American Provincial,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: but that doesn't mean I'm ready for  French Traditional. I loathe the  idea of divorce, Sylvie, but -- if  only Charles had been honest with me --  that's all I ask of anybody -- the  simple truth. But with him, everything  is secrecy and lies. He's hiding  something -- something frightening --  something terrible -- and evil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops as she is aware of a weird figure hovering over her. She wheels, terrified.

dialogues.speaker: PERUVIAN SNOW-MASK
dialogues.text: A strange, grotesque knitted mask that completely covers face except for eyes, nose and mouth. The eyes inside thi particular mask stare down at REGGIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does this belong to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS down to include JEAN-LOUIS, his hand held fir by the man in the mask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Including REGGIE, MAN, SYLVIE and JEAN-LOUIS. REGGIE is t terrified to answer. Realizing this, the man, PETER JOSHU takes off the snow-mask to reveal a handsome, tanned face

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, forgive me. (indicating JEAN-LOUIS) Is this yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating SYLVIE) It's hers. Where'd you find him,  robbing a bank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was throwing snowballs at Baron  Rothschild. (a pause) We don't know each other, do we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, do you think we're going to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know -- how would I know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I already know a great  many people. Until one of them dies  I couldn't possibly meet anyone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Yes, of course. But you will let me  know if anyone goes on the critical  list (he starts off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quitter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning) How's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You give up awfully easy, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eyeing one, then the other, SYLVIE sizes up the situation and rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Viens, Jean-Louis, let us take a  walk. I have never seen a Rothschild  before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SYLVIE and JEAN-LOUIS start off, but not before the boy  squirts PETER with his pistol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drying) Clever fellow -- almost missed me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid you're blocking my view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moving) Sorry. Which view would you like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one you're blocking. This is the  last chance I have -- I'm flying  back to Paris this afternoon. What's  your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter Joshua.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Regina Lampert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there a Mr. Lampert?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it isn't. I'm getting a divorce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, not on my account.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you see, I don't really love  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're honest, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I am -- I'm compulsive about it --  dishonesty infuriates me. Like when  you go into a drugstore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you go in and you ask for some  toothpaste -- the small size -- and  the man brings you the large size.  You tell him you wanted the small  size but he says the large size is  the small size. I always thought the  large size was the largest size, but  he says that the family size, the  economy size and the giant size are  all larger than the large size --  that the large size is the smallest  size there is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there a Mrs. Joshua?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but we're divorced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wasn't a proposal -- I was just  curious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is your husband with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Charles is hardly ever with me.  First it was separate rooms -- now  we're trying it with cities. What do  people call you -- Pete?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Joshua. (turning to go) Well, I've enjoyed talking with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you're angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not -- I've got some packing  to do. I'm also going back to Paris  today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Well, wasn't it Shakespeare who  said: "When strangers do meet they  should erelong see one another again"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shakespeare never said that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's terrible -- you just made it  up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the idea's right, anyway. Are  you going to call me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you in the book?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there only one Charles Lampert?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Her face clouding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord, I hope so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Arc de Triomphe at the far end of the Avenue. CAMERA  PANS to pick up a TAXI as it pulls up before the handsome building. Inside are REGGIE, SYLVIE and JEAN-LOUIS.

dialogues.speaker: TAXI
dialogues.text: As REGGIE climbs out and the DRIVER begins unloading her  suitcases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Sylvie, and thanks. (She turns toward the  house)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JEAN-LOUIS sticks his head out of the taxi window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you get your divorce will you  be going back to America?

dialogues.speaker: THE TAXI
dialogues.text: REGGIE looks at SYLVIE, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to JEAN-LOUIS) Don't you want me to stay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course -- but if you went  back and wrote me a letter --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- you could have the stamps. I'll  get you some here, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REGGIE walks toward the house with the driver, who carrie her cases.  She presses the button that electrically open the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the elevator rises REGGIE gets out, followed by the dr He puts down the bags in front of the apartment door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing him a tip) Merci.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver leaves. She goes to the door and presses the  minuterie, the button that turns on the time-light, and t lights come on. Then she rings the doorbell. There is no  answer. She rings again. Still nothing. Sighing, she digs out her keys and starts to fit it into the lock. At this  moment the minuterie expires, plunging the scene into  darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She finds the button and the light goes on again. She ins the key and turns it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT -- DOOR as it opens and REGGIE steps into the  CLOSE SHOT. She stops, her expression changing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From REGGIE's p.o.v. as CAMERA PANS the entrance hall. It bare -- no furniture, no rug, no pictures, no nothing.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: She stares for a moment, then goes back out into the land

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As REGGIE steps back outside. She looks at the nameplate  beside the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It reads "MR. AND MRS. CHARLES LAMPERT."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REGGIE looks at the plate in disbelief, then turns and hu back into the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As REGGIE hurries into the entrance hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honorine -- !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer. Now, CAMERA FOLLOWING, she goes into the Salon. It is als empty -- stripped bare. There are squares of the wall's  original color where paintings used to hang, the hooks st in the wall. She rushes now, going into the bedroom, CAMERA FOLLOWING  crazily, lurching and careening behind her. The bedroom,  too, is empty. She goes to the built-in wardrobe closets throws open all the doors. Only some hangers remain. She pulls open the drawers -- nothing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles -- !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns, and running now, goes through another door to library, CAMERA FOLLOWING. The rows of shelves are as emp as the rest of the apartment. She begins to turn in a cir looking for something, anything. In a panic she turns and runs out, colliding suddenly with a MAN whom she (and we) have not noticed until the moment of impact. REGGIE screams.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR GRANDPIERRE
dialogues.text: A heavy-set man of no particular age with tobacco-colored hair, and thick glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame Charles Lampert?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Including REGGIE, in a state of near-shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am Inspector Edouard Grandpierre  of the Police Judiciaire. Would you  be so kind as to come with me, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a large metal drawer being opened and an all-too-  familiar shape outlined under a damp sheet of muslin.

dialogues.speaker: OVERHEAD
dialogues.text: Looking straight down at the tops of REGGIE's, GRANDPIERR and an ATTENDANT's head and smack into the open drawer. GRANDPIERRE lifts a corner of the sheet at the bottom and reveals a bare foot with a ticket tied to its big toe. He stoops to read it. Satisfied, he recovers the foot, th moves to the other end to uncover the head.  As the sheet starts to lift:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REGGIE as she looks down into the CAMERA. She closes her  eyes for a moment, then looks again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Madame -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are positive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods again. GRANDPIERRE moves into the SHOT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You loved him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRANDPIERRE nods as he turns to the unseen ATTENDANT. CAMERA suddenly moves as the 'drawer' is slid back into t wall. BLACKNESS comes with a loud clang and continues whi the echo dies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT -- DESK DRAWER (FROM ABOVE) as it is pulled op A photograph of Charles Lampert lies face up in the drawe A hand reaches in and pulls it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Including GRANDPIERRE sitting behind his desk, and REGGIE sitting across from him. The office is as bare as most  policemen's offices. GRANDPIERRE studies the photo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We discovered your husband's body  lying next to the tracks of the Paris- Bourdeaux railroad line. He was  dressed only in his pajamas. Do you  know of any reason why he might have  wished to leave France?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your husband possessed a ticket of  passage on the 'Maranguape.' It sailed  from Bordeaux for Maracaibo this  morning at seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a pause) I'm very confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to rummage through her bag. GRANDPIERRE shoves package of French cigarettes across the desk to her. But pulls a package of nuts out of her bag. She begins separa the shells with her thumb nail and eating the nuts, depos the shells in the ashtray. GRANDPIERRE watches this for a instant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was American?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Swiss. His profession?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't have one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a wealthy man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I suppose so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About how wealthy would you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did he keep his money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides yourself, who is his nearest  relation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exploding) C'est absurde, Madame. To-tale-ment  absurde!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. (pause) I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRANDPIERRE sighs, puts down his pencil and pushes a butt on the desk. He removes a cigar from his desk and inserts into his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you wouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rips the cigar out of his mouth and slams it back into the drawer, closing it fiercely. A UNIFORMED POLICEMAN st his head in the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les effets de Lampert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The POLICEMAN leaves and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Wednesday last your husband sold  the entire contents of the apartment  at public auction. Furniture,  clothing, kitchenware -- everything.  The gallery, in complying with his  wishes, paid him in cash. One million  two hundred and fifty thousand New  Francs. In dollars, a quarter of a  million. The authorities in Bordeaux  have searched his compartment on the  train. They have searched it  thoroughly. They did not find  $250,000, Madame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the desk drawer, puts the cigar back in his mout and lights a match by scratching it against the glass des top before he remembers REGGIE's request. He puts it back the drawer again. The door opens and the POLICEMAN enters again, this time carrying a wicker basket which he deposi on GRANDPIERRE's desk, and leaves. GRANDPIERRE peers into the basket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These few things are all that was  found in the train compartment. There  was no other baggage. Your husband  must have been in a great hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He begins to take them out, placing them on the desk,  identifying each item as he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One wallet containing four thousand  francs -- one agenda -- (pausing, he opens  the notebook) -- his last notation was made  yesterday -- Thursday -- (reading) "Five p.m. -- Jardin des Champs- ElysГ©es" (looking up) Why there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Perhaps he met somebody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly) Obviously. (returning to the  items in the basket) One ticket of passage to South America --  one letter, stamped but unsealed,  addressed to you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lighting up) A letter? May I see it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRANDPIERRE hands her the letter and watches her closely she reads it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) "My dear Regina: I hope you are  enjoying your holiday. Megeve can be  so lovely this time of year. The  days pass very slowly and I hope to  see you soon. As always, Charles.  P.S. Your dentist called yesterday.  Your appointment has been changed." (she looks up, puzzled) Not very much, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We took the liberty of calling your  dentist -- we thought, perhaps, we  would learn something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Your appointment has been  changed. (he smiles at his  little joke, then  returns to the basket) One key to your apartment -- one  comb -- one fountain pen --  one  toothbrush -- one tin of tooth powder (he looks up) -- that is all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slides a sheet of paper and pen across to her, then st to put the things back into the basket while he speaks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you will sign this list you may  take the things with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighing) Is that all? Can I go now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One more question. Is this your  husband's passport?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches into the desk drawer and pulls out a passport  which he hands to her.

dialogues.speaker: PASSPORT
dialogues.text: The cover indicates that it is Swiss. REGGIE's hand opens to a picture of a man -- the man we saw in GRANDPIERRE's  photo. Under it is the name: "CHARLES LAMPERT."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands her another passport.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND PASSPORT
dialogues.text: The cover is American. When it is opened, we see the iden picture, but the name under it reads: "CHARLES VOSS."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this? And this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands her, one at a time, two more passports.

dialogues.speaker: THIRD AND FOURTH PASSPORTS
dialogues.text: One is Italian which, when opened, shows the same photo w the name "CARLO FABRI." The other is Venezuelan, the same photo, and the name "CARLOS MORENO."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you nothing to say, Madame?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REGGIE looks down at the four passports, then back to  GRANDPIERRE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hopefully) It's all right if you want to smoke  your cigar now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is empty as before. Now it is silent, the late  afternoon light coming from outside. REGGIE stands by a  window. A canvas airline bag rests on the floor nearby. Suddenly there is the noise of a DOOR OPENING.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: As her head turns, in alarm, toward the noise. There is a moment of silence, then FOOTSTEPS are heard, coming close

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As PETER enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I phoned but nobody answered. I wanted  to tell you how sorry I am -- and to  find out if there was anything I  could do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you find out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's in all the afternoon papers.  I'm very sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I rang the bell but I don't think  it's working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes it is -- I heard it this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks around for the light switch, then goes to it and flicks it on -- nothing happens. He flicks it a few more  times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They must have turned off the  electricity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shakes her head. PETER looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did everything go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles sold it all -- at auction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what you're going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try and get my old job back at UNESCO,  I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doing what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a simultaneous translator --  like Sylvie, only she's English to  French -- I'm French to English.  That's what I did before I married  Charles. The police probably think I  killed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Instant divorce you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something like that. But I'm sorry  it ended like this -- tossed off a  train like a sack of third-class  mail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Taking her hand) Come on. You can't stay here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know where to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll find you a hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not too expensive -- I'm not a lady  of leisure anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something modest but clean -- and  near enough to UNESCO so you can  take a cab when it rains -- okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods. He picks up the airlines bag and they start out REGGIE stops at the door and looks back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I loved this room -- but Charles  never saw it -- only what was in it.  All those exquisite things -- (looking around) I think I prefer it like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT of a phonograph. A hand appears, starts the re on it spinning, then places the arm at the beginning. An instant later ORGAN MUSIC starts with a roar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT of the coffin. It rests on a low platform, wit bouquet or two of flowers near the head, the lid open. Inside, the face made up to look lifelike (but failing), the remnants of Charles Lampert.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDPIERRE
dialogues.text: The INSPECTOR sits quietly, eyes downcast, staring at his hands in a prayer-like attitude. CAMERA PULLS BACK, revea row after row of empty wooden bench-like seats in the lar dimly-lit, high-ceilinged room. Finally, in the first row REGGIE and SYLVIE are discovered. Besides GRANDPIERRE, th are the only ones present. REGGIE turns around to look at the empty room. They speak in whispers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not exactly what I'd call a  large turn-out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't Charles have any friends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't ask me -- I'm only the widow. (indicating GRANDPIERRE) If Charles had died in bed we wouldn't  even have him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least he knows how to behave at  funerals.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDPIERRE
dialogues.text: His eyes still lowered. CAMERA PANS DOWN to feature his h he is methodically trimming his nails with a small clippe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you no idea who could have done  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until two days ago all I really knew  about Charles was his name -- now it  turns out I didn't even know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front DOOR of the Chapel is heard opening and a shaft daylight streams in. The WOMEN turn.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPEL DOOR
dialogues.text: The short, heavy-set figure of a MAN is outlined against bright outdoor light. He stands for a moment, then closes the door after him. LEOPOLD GIDEON, short-sighted, bald, his middle forties, glances around nervously, like a barn bird. Then he walks down one of the side aisles of the Ch

dialogues.speaker: GRANDPIERRE
dialogues.text: As he watches GIDEON.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: As she watches him.

dialogues.speaker: THE BIER
dialogues.text: GIDEON arrives at the coffin. He stops, looks down at  LAMPERT's body for a moment. Then, suddenly, in rapid  succession, he sneezes six times. He takes a small bottle from his pocket, shakes a pill from it and swallows it dr He turns and walks back up the aisle, looking for a place sit. He comes face to face with GRANDPIERRE, stops, turns sit somewhere else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never seen him before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He must have known Charles pretty  well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you tell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's allergic to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SYLVIE turns and glances at GIDEON. Again, the sound of t DOOR opening interrupts them. They turn to look.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPEL DOOR
dialogues.text: Again the figure of a MAN is outlined in silhouette again the outside brightness. When he closes the door we can se "TEX" PENTHOLLOW, a slim, rangy man with sandy-colored ha a weatherbeaten face, washed-out blue-eyes -- also in his forties. He wears a velvet-corduroy suit, string tie and bright yellow flower in his lapel. A bulldurham tag hangs from his outside breast pocket, dangling from its string. He starts down the aisle toward the bier, CAMERA LEADING  him, and we notice his unsteady gait. He turns to look at the others present. TRAVELING SHOT -- TEX'S P.O.V. MOVING down the aisle. GRANDPIERRE's face, then GIDEON's, then REGGIE's and SYLVIE's -- all staring at CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: THE BIER
dialogues.text: As TEX arrives. He stands staring at LAMPERT's body, sway on his feet until he reaches out and grabs the side of th coffin to steady himself. Then he takes the flower from h lapel and throws it into the open box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heavy Texas accent) Ariva durchy, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As TEX turns away from the coffin and approaches REGGIE a SYLVIE, addressing the latter -- after having first reach for his hat which he discovers he isn't wearing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miz Lampert, ma'am...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SYLVIE points to REGGIE. Unruffled, TEX starts over.  addressing REGGIE this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miz Lampert, ma'am...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie had no call to handling it  this-a-way. He sure didn't. No siree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understa--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But TEX has nodded his head and moved off to find a seat. When he spots GIDEON, the two men stare at each other. Finally, TEX chooses a seat away from him and sits.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPEL DOOR
dialogues.text: It flies open, this time with a bang, and the large MAN w appears almost fills the frame.

dialogues.speaker: TEX
dialogues.text: As the loud noise awakens him with a snort, mid-snore.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOOR
dialogues.text: Closing the door, we see HERMAN SCOBIE, a heavy-weight -- tall and wide, but not fat -- with black hair combed stra back and heavy bushy eyebrows of a matching color, which  meet over his nose and join up. About the same age as the first two men, SCOBIE is dressed in a battered raincoat, hands thrust deep in the pockets. He marches down the ais Looking straight ahead, CAMERA PANNING with him. He stops before the coffin and stares into it.

dialogues.speaker: SCOBIE
dialogues.text: As he stares down into the coffin, his tongue trying to  dislodge a bit of food caught in his teeth. He stares har at the body, squinting his eyes. Then he removes one hand from his pocket, removes a pin from the inside of his lap picks his teeth with it, then slowly lets the hand down,  into the coffin.

dialogues.speaker: SCOBIE'S HAND
dialogues.text: The pin held between thumb and forefinger, he jabs it slo but positively deep into the back of one of the dead man' hands. There is no reaction.

dialogues.speaker: SCOBIE
dialogues.text: He watches the dead man carefully, still squinting. Then  finally satisfied, he returns the pin to his lapel and wa back up the aisle and out of the door, slamming it after  him.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Having watched SCOBIE exit. Suddenly a hand falls on her  shoulder. She jumps in alarm and utters a little cry of  fright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Featuring a funeral ATTENDANT, a cadaverous type (aren't  they all) with a black cut-away coat and an over-solicito unctuous manner. He is eternally bent at the waist, in a  sort of half bow. He offers REGGIE a letter which she tak

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merci, Monsieur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pas du tout, madame, pardon -- pardon --  pardon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He backs off and is gone. REGGIE looks at the letter, bac and front, then starts to open it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The American Embassy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls out the letter and starts to read it.

dialogues.speaker: THE LETTER
dialogues.text: It bears the Great Seal as a letterhead and the typed mes reads: "Dear Mrs. Lampert: Please drop by my office tomorrow at  noon-thirty. I am anxious to discuss the matter of your l husband's death. Sincerely, (signed) H. Bartholomew."

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE AND SYLVIE
dialogues.text: SYLVIE has been reading over REGGIE's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  But if this is a sample  of American diplomacy I'm buying a  fallout shelter.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The fine old building in the Rue Gabriel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As REGGIE leaves the elevator two young DIPLOMATIC TYPES  step in, immersed in conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bluffed the Old Man out of the  last pot -- with a pair of deuces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's so depressing about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I can do it, what are the Russians  doing to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator door closes on them. REGGIE reacts to this a starts down the hall, finally stopping at the door.

dialogues.speaker: DOOR
dialogues.text: It is marked "307-A  H. BARTHOLOMEW." REGGIE checks the  letter, then opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The office is empty, the typewriter on the secretary's de is covered with its plastic shroud. REGGIE enters, looks somebody, notices that the door to the private office is  slightly ajar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tentatively) Hello -- ? (there is no answer) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from the private  office) Is there anything wrong, Miss  Tompkins?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh -- Miss Tompkins isn't here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BARTHOLOMEW comes to the door and looks in. He is a pale  grey-haired man who looks, on first examination, older th his forty-odd years. Sickly would be the word that descri him best -- pallid, consumptive-looking. He wears heavy  tortoise-framed glasses which fall down his nose and caus him to push them back in place every so often with a quic automatic motion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry -- my secretary must have  gone to lunch. You are -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Lampert -- Mrs. Charles Lampert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at his watch) Come in, Mrs. Lampert. You're quite  late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He motions for her to enter, standing aside to let her do so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small cubicle -- there is a silver-framed photo of thre kids on the desk. BARTHOLOMEW indicates a chair, then goe behind his desk and sits. A can of lighter fluid stands o on the desk and a crumpled hankie beside it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me for a moment, Mrs. Lampert --  it's a stubborn little devil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He works at a stain on his necktie with lighter fluid and hankie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dry-cleaningwise, things are all  fouled up. I had a good man -- an  excellent man on the Rue Ponthieu,  but H.Q. asked us to use the plant  here in the building -- to ease the  gold outflow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bartholomew -- are you sure you  know who I am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up) Charles Lampert's widow -- yes? (going back to the  tie) Last time I sent out a tie only the  spot came back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up at her, laughs silently, then goes back to hi tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VoilГ ! As they say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts away the lighter fluid in a desk drawer, smells t hankie, passes on it, then sticks it in his pocket. He opens another drawer and pulls out various sandwiches  wrapped in waxpaper, a salt and pepper shaker, a tube of  mustard, a bottle of red wine and two Dixie cups.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have some, please. I've got... (checking) ...liverwurst -- liverwurst -- chicken  and -- liverwurst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He uncorks the wine, fills a cup and begins eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what C.I.A. is, Mrs.  Lampert?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't suppose it's an airline, is  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Central Intelligence Agency -- C.I.A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean spies and things like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only we call them agents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We? You mean you're --?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone has to do it, Mrs. Lampert --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, it's just that I didn't  think that you people were supposed  to admit --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not an agent, Mrs. Lampert --  I'm an administrator -- a desk jockey --  trying to run a bureau of overworked  men with under-allocated funds.  Congress seems to think that all a  spy needs --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- That all he needs is a code  book and a cyanide pill and he's in  business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's all this got to do with me,  Mr. Bartholomew?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his mouth full) Your husband was wanted by the U. S.  government.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I have a sandwich, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands her a sandwich and fills a wine-cup for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To be more specific, he was wanted  by this agency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eating) So that was it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. We knew him, of course, by his  real name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost choking) His -- real -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Voss -- Charles Voss. All right,  Mrs. Voss -- (taking a photo from  his desk) -- I'd like you to look at this  photograph, please -- by the way,  you saw this one, didn't you? (indicating the kids  on the desk) Scott, Cathy, and Ham, Jr.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very sweet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't they?  Now look at this one,  Mrs. Voss, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop calling me that! Lampert's the  name on the marriage license.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- and tell me if you recognize  anyone. Just a moment. Have a good  look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches back into the drawer and pulls out a glass whi he gives her.

dialogues.speaker: PHOTO
dialogues.text: FOUR MEN, all in army uniform, sitting behind a table. Th glass is held over the first, magnifying the face.

dialogues.speaker: PHOTO
dialogues.text: It's a photo of a young CHARLES LAMPERT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Charles!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks so young -- when was this  taken?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1944. The next face, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The glass and CAMERA move to the next man -- a young TEX.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the man who came to the funeral  yesterday -- I'm sure of it -- a  tall man in a corduroy suit and string  tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does the name Tex Penthollow mean  anything to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The glass and CAMERA move to the third face -- a young GI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- and he was there, too -- a  little fatter now -- and less hair --  but it's the same one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know him, Mrs. Vo -- Mrs.  Lampert? Leopold W. Gideon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last one, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The glass and CAMERA move to the fourth face -- a young  SCOBIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a face you don't forget -- he  was there too --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herman Scobie. And you've never seen  him before, either?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a pause, regarding  her) Mrs. Lampert, I'm afraid you're in a  great deal of danger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danger? Why should I be in any danger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're Charles Voss's wife -- now  that he's dead you're their only  lead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bartholomew -- if you're trying  to frighten me you're doing a really  first-rate job! (she takes another  sandwich)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, do what we ask, Mrs. Lampert --  it's your only chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gladly, only I don't know what you  want! You haven't told me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, haven't I? The money -- Mrs.  Lampert -- the money. The $250,000  Charles Voss received from the  auction. Those three men want it,  too -- they want it very badly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's Charles's money, not theirs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) Oh, Mrs. Lampert! I'd love to see  you try and convince them of that! (drying his eyes) Oh, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then whose is it? His or theirs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she looks at him for  a moment) Oh, I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm afraid we want it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I don't have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's impossible. You're the only  one who could have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry it's impossible. It's the  truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BARTHOLOMEW is silent for a moment, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you've got the money all right --  you just don't know you've got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bartholomew -- if I had a quarter  of a million dollars, believe me,  I'd know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nevertheless, Mrs Lampert -- you've  got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean it's just lying around  someplace -- all that cash?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or a safe deposit key, a certified  check, a baggage claim -- you look  for it, Mrs. Lampert -- I'm quite  sure you'll find it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look for it, Mrs. Lampert -- look  just as hard and as fast as you can.  You may not have a great deal of  time. Those men know you have it  just as surely as we do. You won't  be safe until the money's in our  hands. Is that clear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REGGIE nods. He writes something on a pad of paper and te it off, handing it to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's where you're to call me --  day or night. It's a direct line to  both my office and my apartment.  Don't lose it, Mrs. Lampert -- and  please don't tell anyone about coming  to see me. It could prove fatal for  them as well as yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute -- you think those  three men killed Charles, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've no proof, of course, but we  rather think so, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there you are! Charles had the  money with him -- so whoever killed  him has it -- they have it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BARTHOLOMEW shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimly) Because they're still here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I said, Mrs Lampert -- I'm afraid  you're in a great deal of danger.  Remember what happened to Charles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REGGIE takes the last sandwich and begins eating furiousl

dialogues.speaker: GUIGNOL.
dialogues.text: One of the French Punch and Judy shows set up on certain  days in the small park alongside the broad avenue between the Rond Point and the Place de la Concorde. At the momen Judy, as always, is beating Punch with a bat. The sound o CHILDREN laughing and screaming can be heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting on small benches lined up to face the stage. Thei attention is fixed on the show, their belief totally susp by the play as only children's can be -- laughing at the  slapstick, booing the villain, frightened by the perils.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Sitting on the last bench, next to some CHILDREN. They ar laughing but she isn't -- she just watches, her attention caught up but her face void of emotion. The bench is too for her, forcing her knees up almost under her chin. After a moment, PETER comes up behind her and, stepping o the benches, sits beside her. She doesn't seem to notice. [Throughout the following scene the CHILDREN and the ACTO can be heard in the b.g.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reggie -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns and looks at him for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (vaguely) Hallo, Peter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You telephoned me to meet you. I've  been standing on the corner back  there -- waiting for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry -- I heard the children  laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ROAR from the CHILDREN. REGGIE and PETER turn toward th stage.

dialogues.speaker: GUIGNOL
dialogues.text: PUNCH and JUDY are arguing loudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you understand French?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm still having trouble with English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man and the woman are married --

dialogues.speaker: GUIGNOL STAGE
dialogues.text: PUNCH and JUDY are batting each other on the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I can see that -- they're batting  each other over the head with clubs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, JUDY knocks Punch out of sight and a PUPPET wear a three-cornered hat appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that with the hat?

dialogues.speaker: GRANDPIERRE
dialogues.text: Wearing a hat, he stands off in the background, watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the policeman -- he wants to  arrest Judy for killing Punch.

dialogues.speaker: GUIGNOL STAGE
dialogues.text: JUDY and the POLICEMAN are batting one another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's she saying now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That she's innocent -- she didn't do  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She did it, all right -- take it  from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PUNCH's head appears on the other side of the stage, says something, then ducks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Punch, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course? I thought he was dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's only pretending, to teach her a  lesson -- only -- (her face clouding) only he is dead, Peter -- I saw him --  he's not pretending. Somebody threw  him off a train. What am I going to  do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles was mixed up in something terrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you'd let me help you. Whatever  it is, it doesn't sound like the  sort of thing that a woman can handle  all by herself.

dialogues.speaker: GUIGNOL STAGE
dialogues.text: JUDY has gotten the upper hand is now batting the POLICEM brains out. CLOSE SHOT -- GRANDPIERRE as he winces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you got a mirror? (she nods) Give it to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands it to him and he holds it in front of her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right there, between your eyes --  see? Worry lines. You're much too  young and too pretty to have anything  like that. How about making me vice- president in charge of cheering you  up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jumping at the  suggesting) Starting tonight?

dialogues.speaker: EMCEE.
dialogues.text: He stands on the dance floor in front of a five piece Lat dance band, a spotlight on him, wearing his professional  smile as he speaks into a mike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bonsoir mesdames et messieurs, good  evening ladies and gentlemen, guten  Abend, meine Damen und Herren -- ce  soir, comme tous les soirs,  l'attraction ici, au Black Sheep  Club, c'est vous! Venez, mesdames et  messieurs, step right up, ladies and  gentlemen, kommen Sie her, meine  Damen en Herren, avanti, signore e  signori -- avanti!

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE AND PETER
dialogues.text: At their table. REGGIE is dressed in a lovely Givenchy dr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was all that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fun and games. Evidently we're the  floorshow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean you and me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, everyone. Come on -- avanti,  avanti!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rises and pulls him along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Including the dance floor as most of the patrons go to it laughing self-consciously and looking around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Г‰coutez bien -- les rГЁgles sont tres  simples -- the rules are very easy --  deux Г©quipes -- two teams -- each  with one orange -- une orange --  eine apfelsine -- un' arrancia --  held under the chin, like so -- (does it) comme Г§a -- and passed to the player  behind you -- sans vous servir de  vos mains -- using nothing but the  chin -- no hands -- and keeping the  orange at all costs from touching  the floor. Commencez, Mesdames et  Messieurs -- begin, ladies and  gentlemen -- signore e signori,  comminciate!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The EMCEE now circulates, forming teams, telling the patr to line up, making sure there is a woman next to every ma REGGIE and PETER are the second couple in their line. Then the EMCEE picks up a basket of oranges and places on under the chin, held securely against the chest, of each at the head of the line. Blowing a whistle, a signal for game to begin and the band to play, the men turn to the w behind them and attempt to transfer the oranges from unde their chins to under the chins of the women -- without us their hands. (This maneuver can only be accomplished by embracing one' partner passionately and firmly pressing the orange again the partner's throat until he or she can grip it tightly  enough with the chin to turn and offer it to the person n in line, where the process begins anew. However, the slig miscalculation, which can be brought about by any number human frailties -- haste, modesty, inhibition or lack of ordination -- will surely result in losing control of the orange so that it either falls to the floor [where it can only be picked up by the chin] or it starts to roll and s from its proper place to some other, less proper, spot on the human anatomy, forcing the man or the woman to retrie it -- again, with the chin only. This latter is an activi which can prove extremely satisfying to old friends, or e new friends who wish to become old friends, but can only a torment for total strangers and/or the English).

dialogues.speaker: ORANGE GAME
dialogues.text: Some of the couples in various states of confusion,  entanglement and intimacy -- all of them, naturally,  hilarious.

dialogues.speaker: PETER AND GIRL
dialogues.text: It is his turn to take the orange from a very short, but  quite shapely young girl in a strapless dress (held up by abundance of cantilever). PETER 'takes' when he sees the  twin obstacles which might -- and probably will -- encumb the game but increase his worldly experience. The contest begins: because of her stature he is forced t move in low, making the ordinary embrace needed for succe difficult, if not impossible. Then, inexorably, the orang starts to slip down the GIRL's front. Manfully he goes af it.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: She is enjoying it thoroughly.

dialogues.speaker: PETER AND GIRL
dialogues.text: Bending over backwards, in a sort of frontal half-nelson, PETER makes a last valiant effort and voilГ , grips the o under his chin -- amid much cheering and congratulations  from members of his TEAM. Now he turns to REGGIE and they face one another for a mo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: En garde.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lay on, MacDuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They go at it, working their bodies together to make it a possible. Then, for a moment, the game and the onlookers  seem less important than their proximity. But, alas, they are too good despite themselves and the transfer is  accomplished -- again with appreciative cheers from the T REGGIE, with the orange now tucked firmly under her chin, turns to the next team-member in line and is locked in an embrace before she realizes her partner is LEOPOLD GIDEON the short, fat, balding man seen at the funeral and later BARTHOLOMEW's photo. REGGIE starts to draw back but GIDEON holds her tightly. Putting his chin around the orange he is able to speak qu in REGGIE's ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her eyes show her fright as he whispers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Lampert --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't Charles tell you, Mrs. Lampert?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't belong to you, Mrs. Lampert --  you do know that, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Lampert, any morning now you  could wake up dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave me alone -- !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead, Mrs. Lampert -- like last week's  news -- like Charles, Mrs. Lampert --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it!

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE'S AND GIDEON'S FEET
dialogues.text: As REGGIE hauls off and kicks GIDEON full in the shin.

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON
dialogues.text: He stiffens as the pain registers. Instead of shouting he merely closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Including REGGIE and GIDEON and PETER standing by, as wel as some spectators. PETER comes quickly forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reggie -- what's the trouble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REGGIE realizes that GIDEON no longer offers any resistan She steps back, leaving GIDEON holding the orange, foolis under his chin, his eyes still closed. REGGIE stares at h for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He -- he was stepping on my foot.

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON
dialogues.text: Slowly, his eyes open and tears stream from them, rolling down his cheeks. He speaks while holding the orange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me -- it was quite  unintentional, I'm sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GIDEON turns to the woman behind him and the game resumes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting off) Wait for me -- I won't be long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes off toward the rear of the club and starts down flight of stairs.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Watching her go, a concerned look on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small, dimly lit area with a door to the combination me women's room and a 'phone cabin with a solid door. The music and shouting from upstairs float down. REGGIE c down the stairs and goes to the 'phone, flicking on the l and closing the door after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REGGIE takes a jeton ('phone token) from her bag and drop it in the slot. Then she takes out a slip of paper (the o given her by BARTHOLOMEW) and dials the number written on it. She listens to it ring, then evidently he answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into 'phone) Mr. Bartholomew -- it's me, Reggie  Lampert -- listen Mr. Bartholomew:  I've seen one of the (she stops) Mr. Bartholomew? Can you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She realizes she has not pushed the button which takes he coin and allows the party at the other end to hear her vo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello -- Mr. Bartholomew -- it's me,  Regina Lam...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly the door of the booth opens and REGGIE wheels to look, slamming the receiver down as she does.

dialogues.speaker: 'PHONE BOOTH
dialogues.text: TEX PENTHOLLOW, the second man from the funeral (and phot the man in the corduroy suit and string tie, stands in th doorway, his face calm, a hand-rolled but unlit cigarette his mouth. He has put one foot up against the side of the door so she can't leave. REGGIE stares at him, terrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howdy, Miz Lampert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wha -- what do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TEX takes a book of matches from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I want, Miz Lampert...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- no, I'm don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on now -- sure you do. An' you'd  better give it to me, Miz Lampert --  cuz I ain't foolin'. No sireebob!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He strikes a match and lights his cigarette, holding the  burning match in his hand afterward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TEX, without a word, throws the still-lit match into the  booth, onto REGGIE's lap. She beats it out frantically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TEX lights another match and throws it into her lap. She  beats this one out too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't make too much noise, Miz Lampert --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lights another match and reaches out toward her hair w it. She shrinks back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could get a whole lot worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he throws it into her lap. As he continues to speak punctuates each phrase or so with another lit match. REGG is too busy beating them out to do anything else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It belongs to me, Miz Lampert -- an'  if you don't give it to me your life  ain't gonna be worth the paper it's  printed on. You savvy what I'm sayin',  Miz Lampert?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please stop -- please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think on it real careful-like,  Miz Lampert -- y'hear?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: As she frantically beats out the matches, her eyes on her work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're insane, absolutely insane!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up, then blinks her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no one there. REGGIE rises and steps out of the  booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As REGGIE looks around. There is no one there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As REGGIE returns, sits and starts to put another jeton i the slot. She notices her hand is shaking. She reaches ba into her bag, removes a piece of candy, puts it into her  mouth and leans her head back against the wall, closing h eyes. Suddenly the door opens and REGGIE shrieks -- but this ti it is PETER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a sigh of relief) Having a nervous breakdown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REGGIE and PETER enter the deserted lobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't said a word since we  left the club -- what happened back  there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I -- I'm not sure if I'm supposed to  tell you or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I follow you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said if I told anybody it could  prove fatal for them as well as me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who said?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I'm not supposed to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop this nonsense! If you're in  some sort of trouble I want to know  about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop bullying me. Everybody's bullying  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you were -- you called it  nonsense. Being murdered in cold  blood isn't nonsense. Wait until it  happens to you sometime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes to the desk, followed by PETER, where the NIGHT  CLERK greets them sleepily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bonsoir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bonsoir. Quarante-deux, s'il vous  plait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The NIGHT CLERK gets the key off a hook and hands it to  REGGIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bonne nuit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to PETER) Would you mind seeing me to the door?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They go to the elevator where he opens the door for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As REGGIE and PETER enter the small cage. It is somewhat  cramped, forcing them to stand close together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is quite a place for making  friends, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He presses the button and the elevator starts to rise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said this afternoon that your  husband was mixed up in something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (busy examining the  cleft in his chin) How do you shave in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What your husband was mixed up in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I know it's asking you to  stretch your imagination, but can't  you pretend for a moment that I'm a  woman and that you're a --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you know I could already be  arrested for transporting a minor  above the first floor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the street where you live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about once more around the park?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches across her and opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As REGGIE leaves the elevator, followed by PETER. They wa to her door. There is a moment of silence as she looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (imitating PETER) Him: 'Do you mind if I come in for a  nightcap, Reggie?' Her: 'Well -- it  is awfully late.' Him: 'Just one,  all right?' Her: 'Promise you'll  behave yourself.' Him: 'Sorry, baby,  I never make promises I can't keep.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would you like a spanking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would you like a punch in the  nose? Stop treating me like a child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then stop acting like one. If you're  really in some kind of trouble, I'd  like to hear about it. Otherwise,  it's late, I'm tired and I'm going  home to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what's wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and leaves. She smiles slightly, then turns and  puts the key into the door and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Featuring the door. REGGIE enters, then stops abruptly, t doorknob still in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room has been torn apart. And standing in the center HERMAN SCOBIE, the large man in the battered raincoat. He starts slowly advancing toward REGGIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is it, lady -- where've you  got it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (terrified) I don't know -- I don't know! I don't --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops as she sees something.

dialogues.speaker: SCOBIE'S HAND
dialogues.text: Instead of a human hand there is a twin-pronged metal one

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCOBIE sees where REGGIE is staring; looks down at it him then lunges at her, raising the hand to strike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want it -- give it to me -- it's  mine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hand is starting to come down. REGGIE, moving quickly turns and flies out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming) Peter -- ! Peter -- !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As REGGIE runs out, slamming the door after her, the meta hand crashes against the wooden panel inside the door and splinters through it, visible on this side now. Petrified with fear, REGGIE can only stare dumbly at the protruding claw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As PETER comes running up to her. He sees the metal hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man -- he tried to kill me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pulling her aside, PETER takes hold of the key (still in outside lock) and turns it slowly and quietly. Then, usin all his weight, he slams the door open as far as it will making sure to hold it that way as he steps in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside, PETER pulls back the door and slugs the startled  SCOBIE full on the jaw. His head bangs against the wall b he manages to raise a foot and push PETER violently away, sending him sprawling back, toppling across the bed and o head first, onto the floor on the other side, where he  disappears. Hurrying, SCOBIE puts his foot against the do and pushes it away, ripping his metal hand free. He then rushes to the open window and climbs out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REGGIE waits anxiously. When she hears nothing, she ginge looks into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (entering cautiously) Peter -- ? (alarmed) Peter! Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Showing the disarranged room, empty of people. Then, slow PETER's hand appears from behind the bed, shaking groggil REGGIE rushes to him and helps him sit on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter -- are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I sprained my pride. (He looks around) Where'd he go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of the window, I guess -- I didn't  see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PETER goes, unsteady on his feet, to the window and looks out. He then turns back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lock the door and the window -- and  don't let anyone in except me. I'll  be back in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be careful, Peter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (one leg over the  sill) You took the words right out of my  mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He climbs out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside the window to REGGIE's room is a small, false bal consisting mostly of railing, with barely enough room bet it and the building's facade for a man to stand. PETER ap and looks down over the railing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOOTING STRAIGHT DOWN; there is no one on the street and is too far to jump.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: He now looks around. REGGIE's is the last such balcony on one side, but there are two or three on the other. PETER climbs over the railing and, holding on to it with hand, reaches for the railing on the next balcony.

dialogues.speaker: PETER'S HAND
dialogues.text: As it stretches for the railing; it is several inches sho of touching it.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: As he straightens up and prepares to jump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the GROUND. PETER, high above, jumps to the next bal

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: As he climbs over the railing of the second balcony. He s a light coming through the window and looks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PETER leaves the window quickly, climbing over the railin on his way to the next balcony. As he does, the following exchange is heard (in British English).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it now, Pamela?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It happened again, Henry -- another  strange man peered in the window at  me and then went away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad luck, Pamela.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the GROUND as PETER jumps to the next balcony.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: As he climbs over the rail to the third balcony. There is light coming from this window, too. PETER looks in.

dialogues.speaker: WINDOW
dialogues.text: Inside the room are GIDEON, TEX, and SCOBIE in the midst a heated discussion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was a dumb move, Herman -- a  dumb move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then some. If you'd only told us  you was goin' to her room we could've  kept 'em busy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- but sneakin' in there on your own  that-a-way, why, man, you was bound  to get yore tokus kicked. I mean,  what'd you think he'd do -- walk up  'n' shake you by that hand o' yores?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, Herman -- you didn't  leave me much choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all turn toward the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As PETER climbs in through the window and joins them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to SCOBIE) I didn't hurt you, did I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCOBIE shakes his head and turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eagerly) Never mind that -- did you get the  money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could I with the three Marx  Brothers breathing down my neck? You  said you'd let me handle it alone -- ! The girl trusts me. If she's got  it, I'll find out about it. But you've  got to leave me alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to GIDEON and TEX) We took all the chances. The money  belongs to us, not him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be un-neighborly-like, Herman --  don't forget he done us a little ol'  favor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He took care of Charlie for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to PETER) We appreciate it, really we do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But who asked him? Three shares are  enough -- I'd say he's out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A third of nothing is nothing, Herman.  Make up your minds -- she's waiting  for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) I don't see how another twenty-four  hours could hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoot no, not after all these years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he gets it out of your share,  not mine! Not mine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCOBIE turns and storms out of the door, slamming it. GIDEON begins sneezing, takes a bottle of pills from his  pocket and swallows two white tablets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suggest you get about your business --  nothing soothes Herman like success.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckling) That's right -- it's like ticklin' a  alligator's belly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's got the room next to hers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me. How come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get another one, will you? I'm going  to need it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PETER starts for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you do find the money -- you won't  forget t' tell us about it, will  you, fella?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning at the door) Don't worry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I ain't worryin' -- but see this  pudgy little fella here? (indicating GIDEON) He worries -- an' he's even meaner'n  I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she waits anxiously, smoking a cigarette. There is a K at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's me. Peter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REGGIE unlocks the door and opens it. PETER enters and sh closes the door again --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was no trace of him. All right,  Reggie -- suppose you tell me what  this is all about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are three men -- he's one of  them -- they think I have something  that belongs to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A quarter of a million dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PETER is silent for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it isn't -- where's the money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  Those men killed  Charles to get it. But he must not  have had it with him on the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So they think he left it with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he didn't! I've looked everywhere -- (tears welling) And if I don't find it -- (wailing) Those men going to kill me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She falls in his arms to be comforted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, they won't -- I won't let them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sobbing) Please help me, Peter -- you're the  only one I can trust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I'll help -- I told you I  would, didn't I? Come on now --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes out his handkerchief and dries her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so hungry I could faint. (trying to smile) I've -- I've gotten your suit all  wet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right -- it's a drip-dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, you've got to promise me  something. Promise you'll never lie  the way Charles did. Why do people  have to tell lies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Usually it's because they want  something -- and they're afraid the  truth won't get it for them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you tell lies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
